etymologies: Old English weorpan (verb), wearp (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch werpen and German werfen ‘to throw’. Early verb senses included ‘throw’ and ‘hit with a missile’; the sense ‘bend’ dates from late Middle English. The noun was originally a term in weaving (see warp (sense 2 of the noun))

definitions: become or cause to become bent or twisted out of shape, typically as a result of the effects of heat or dampness

examples.text: wood has a tendency to warp

shortDefinitions: make or become bent or twisted out of shape

definitions: cause to become abnormal or strange; have a distorting effect on

examples.text: your judgment has been warped by your obvious dislike of him

definitions: move (a ship) along by hauling on a rope attached to a stationary object on shore

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

examples.text: crew and passengers helped warp the vessels through the shallow section

shortDefinitions: (of ship) move or be moved along by hauling on rope attached to stationary object ashore

definitions: (of a ship) move by being hauled on a rope attached to a stationary object.
(in weaving) arrange (yarn) so as to form the warp of a piece of cloth

examples.text: cotton string will be warped on the loom in the rug-weaving process

shortDefinitions: (in weaving) arrange yarn so as to form warp of piece of cloth

definitions: cover (land) with a deposit of alluvial soil by natural or artificial flooding

examples.text: the main canal may be cut so as to warp the lands on each side of it

shortDefinitions: cover land with deposit of alluvial soil by natural or artificial flooding

definitions: a twist or distortion in the shape or form of something

examples.text: the head of the racket had a curious warp

shortDefinitions: twist or distortion in shape of something

definitions: relating to or denoting (fictional or hypothetical) space travel by means of distorting space-time
shortDefinitions: of fictional or hypothetical space travel by means of distorting space-time

definitions: an abnormality or perversion in a person's character

examples.text: no mind is more capable of warps than his

shortDefinitions: abnormality or perversion in person's character

definitions: (in weaving) the threads on a loom over and under which other threads (the weft) are passed to make cloth

examples.text: the warp and weft are the basic constituents of all textiles
rugby is woven into the warp and weft of South African society

shortDefinitions: (in weaving) threads on loom over and under which other threads weft are passed to make cloth

definitions: a rope attached at one end to a fixed point and used for moving or mooring a ship.
shortDefinitions: rope attached at one end to fixed point and used for moving or mooring ship

examples.text: the warp or muddy deposit dug from an old riverbed
